They also play an important part in influencing both the capacity to restrain migration and the ability to attract new industry. Here is all the more reason for not subjecting the service industries in the development areas to the full rate of the S.E.T.
Special attention was given to tourism in that White Paper. Indeed, there were constant references to the importance of tourism to the economy of Scotland. We are now told that the problems facing the tourist industry are being examined by the Government. The Minister of State, Board of Trade, said in Standing Committee the other day that something must be done to help certain sections of the hotel and catering industry. We have had similar statements today.
I do not have much faith in these declarations of good intent. What do they mean? We had another reference in the White Paper—[HON. MEMBERS: "Oh, no."] It is time that hon. Gentlemen opposite were reminded of what their Government have said. They must listen to their words and eat them. On page 8 of the White Paper it was stated that special attention would be given to tourism. What special attention has been given? First, the investment allowances were withdrawn and now the industry is having S.E.T. imposed on it.
I welcome the enthusiasm which Liberal hon. Members have made expressing for tourism. This is in contrast with the way in which they trooped into the Government Lobby not long ago in support of the White Paper which proposed the complete withdrawal of investment allowances from the industry.

The hon. Gentleman may recall that in the debate on that Bill we indicated that we wanted the tourist industry to be included for the new investment grants, but that, in principle, we accepted it as a considerable extension from the old development district scheme which we had under the Conservatives. My constituency benefited not at all under the Conservative Government.

Whatever the hon. Gentleman may or may not have said
during the debate on that Bill, I am referring to what hon. Members of the Liberal Party did months before the Bill, when they voted for the White Paper removing the investment allowances. I do not recall any such qualification then. When they realised the enormity of what they had done, they tried to find a way out later.
Tourism depends on part-time workers, and S.E.T. will hit the industry hard because of that. The industry is not overstaffed but understaffed, so that S.E.T. is irrelevant to the labour situation in the industry. If the tax in the development areas forces people out of the services industries, where will they go? There is no alternative manufacturing employment in many parts of Scotland. If they are squeezed out of employment in the service industries, some will find employment in manufacturing—but in England and not in Scotland—while others will simply become unemployed through losing their jobs, and we have heard a lot about that.
The part-time worker who will suffer most is less mobile than other workers. Often she is the married woman who cannot leave her husband and family and join the march South to find work. The social consequences of this tax are serious indeed for Scotland. If hotels do not reduce their staff—remembering that they must hold their staff if they are to keep up the standard of service they must offer—they will, it is estimated, have to increase their charges by 10 per cent. and this will have a serious effect on their ability to compete.
It is already cheaper to take a fortnight's holiday with B.E.A. from London to the Costa Brava than it is to take a fortnight's holiday with B.E.A. in Argyll. S.E.T. may well make this difference even greater. [Interruption.] I wish that the hon. Member for Coatbridge and Airdrie (Mr. Dempsey) would rise to his feet if he wishes to intervene, and not sit there mumbling.
I was saying that the hon. Gentleman is making a rather wild statement without producing the facts of the relevant costs.

I do not have the precise figures with me, but I assure the
hon. Gentleman that he will find them in B.E.A.'s holiday brochure in the transport office. He will see that the difference in cost between going to Argyll for a fortnight from London is £1 or £2 more than spending a fortnight on the Costa Brava.
This tax will increase this difference even more. This will mean, first, that the English visitor to Scotland will find it more attractive financially to go abroad, which will add a charge to our balance of payments, while, secondly, the overseas visitor coming to Europe will find it more attractive financially to go to Spain or Italy than to come to Scotland. Thus, we may lose both English and foreign visitors to Scotland. Only under a Labour Government do we lose on the swings and also lose on the roundabouts.
7.0 a.m.
I ask the Chancellor how he reconciles this tax with what has been said for months by the Government about the importance of the service industries in Scotland? How can this tax further the work of the Highlands and Islands Development Board? Will he tell us how this tax will help forestry in the North? How will it help the growth of the tourist industry? How will it solve the labour shortage in the construction industry? How will it promote the development of agriculture? All these are critical questions and all were thought to be part of Government policy in view of the declarations by the Government in the last few months. Now they have been shown by this tax to be a sham.
My hon. Friend the Member for South Angus (Mr. Bruce-Gardyne) referred to the first paragraph of the White Paper on the Scottish Economy and gave figures showing the Government's targets in January for increased employment in Scotland. The paragraph told us that 130,000 new jobs would need to be created by 1970 to take account of the loss of employment in the older industries and provide a net overall gain in employment. Of those 130,000 jobs, the White Paper told us, 50,000 would be in manufacturing industry, 20,000 in the construction industry and 60,000 in the service industries. Thus, 50,000 jobs were to be in manufacturing industry, and a total of 80,000 in the service industries.
A few days ago I asked the Government, and did not get a reply, what
changes they intended in this forecast. I presume that the White Paper was written before the Selective Employment Tax was dreamed up. I cannot believe that in January the Secretary of State for Scotland or anyone else thought that there would be a Selective Employment Tax. Indeed, the whole nature of the tax shows that it has been a rushed and botched job. Can the Chancellor tell us what effect the tax will have on this forecast? If, as we are constantly assured, one purpose of the tax is to squeeze people out of the service industries into manufacturing industries, the Secretary of State's forecast can no longer hold good. It has been overtaken by events not within the control of the Secretary of State.
There is a serious problem here. If the Chancellor maintains that the forecast of employment in Scotland in 1970 is not changed but holds good, that in itself is a complete reason for getting rid of the Selective Employment Tax in Scotland.

We have been discussing this Amendment for am hour and three-quarters now. In its scope it is very similar to the Amendment we discussed previously at rather greater length. That Amendment dealt with development areas in general. This Amendment is confined to one aspect of what it describes as regional planning areas—to summarise it—which have a higher level of unemployment.
We have had many speeches from hon. Members representing Scottish constituencies. They have treated this as if it were, on the face of it, a Scottish debate. But I would remind them that there is nothing in the terms of the Amendment to confine it to Scotland. We had a contribution from the hon. Lady the Member for Tynemouth (Dame Irene Ward), perfectly in order, of course, speaking on behalf of the interests of the North-East.
I would only say to those hon. Members who complain about the absence of the Scottitsh Minister that if they had wanted, as they apparently did, to turn this into a specifically Scottish debate, the normal practice would have been to intimate that fact through the usual channels, and the usual arrangements could have been made. I apologise to
hon. Members opposite if they have to put up with a mere Irishman replying to a Scottish debate. Of course, there could have been a large number of speeches from hon. Members from Northern Ireland on this Amendment. They have a problem of high unemployment. But, of course, their particular problems are the subject of other Amendments which have been selected later. So, I would say with respect, are a good many of the matters which have been canvassed during this debate, and I propose to leave our arguments on them till we reach the appropriate Amendments.
Having listened to the speeches made on the various Amendments which we have been discussing, I am led to conclude that all the arguments we get on the roundabouts are arguments which we also get upon the swings. I remember replying to a debate many hours ago dealing with the proposal to exempt the single or first employee. I remember hearing then the same arguments about the tourist industry in the Highlands, the single employee in the Highlands and the small industry in the Highlands, and I had that eerie feeling that I had been here before when I was listening to the arguments in the present debate.
As I say, we have selected special groups of Amendments dealing with part-time workers and with the tourist industry, and we shall come to those, so I hope hon. Members will not think I am being disrespectful to their Amendments if I ask them to await with patience our answers when we come to those Amendments.
Turning to the subject matter of this Amendment, the proposal that there should be a special exemption—it is put in the form of a rate of 1d., but in effect it is an exemption—for areas of high unemployment, I can summarise what I have to say shortly, because it is in effect the same answer as my right hon. Friend the Chief Secretary gave in the last debate, pointing out—I will not weary the Committee by summarising the points again—the many measures which have been taken to bring new employment and industry to these areas to assist development and to reduce unemployment in those areas.
Hon. Members who have complained that there is not a Scottish Minister here
have at least had the satisfaction of having their arguments ably answered by many of my hon. Friends representing Scottish constituencies and who have added, from their great knowledge and experience, to the list of matters which my right hon. Friend the Chief Secretary itemised in the last debate, giving chapter and verse of the very low figures of unemployment in the areas which they represent in Scotland, reminding the Committee of what the Government have done in such matters as the shipbuilding industry and the bringing of the Dounreay project to Scotland. We had from the hon. Member for Perth and East Perthshire (Mr. MacArthur) most important confirmation of this when he was arguing that the reduction in unemployment in certain of these areas was due to the policies initiated by the previous Government.
Let us accept the hon. Gentleman's hypothesis for the moment. We need not argue about the extent to which those policies have been added to by the further policies since the present Government have been in power. But the point that he has made—which it is common ground is a valid one—is that as a result of the measures which have been taken to assist Scotland, the Scottish economy now is very much stronger than it was, and he is really conceding the point of the Chancellor which was attacked at the very outset of this debate by his hon. Friend the Member for South Angus (Mr. Bruce-Gardyne).
It is precisely the difference between the state of the Scottish economy now and at the time when the right hon. and learned Gentleman the Member for the Wirrall (Mr. Selwyn Lloyd) introduced and legislated for, but never put into effect, his payroll tax, which explains why it has been possible for the Chancellor to introduce this tax now.
This also relates to the point made by my hon. Friend in the very first intervention from this side of the Committee in this debate when he pointed out that if it is not to be this tax, and if the Chancellor is to find other forms of tax to raise the additional revenue which it is generally agreed on both sides he must do in his Budget, the alternatives are likely to weigh rather more heavily upon Scotland than does this tax.
My hon. Friend drew particular attention to one of the possibilities, which was widely canvassed among those who speculate about what the Budget might be, and he pointed out what the damaging effect on Scotland might have been if there had been an increase in Purchase Tax relating to motor vehicles or an increase in the vehicle licence duty.
When considering these general challenges to the Selective Employment Tax, we have got to judge the tax against possible alternatives, and the alternatives would have been likely to have more serious effects upon Scotland than hon. Gentlemen are fearing from this tax.

But would the hon. Gentleman not agree that because of the wording of this Amendment, if the Government's regional policies work as they say they will work, then the Amendment would not come into operation and there would be no need to create additional revenue?

That point has been very ably answered by my hon. Friend, who pointed out that making an exemption as restricted as this is something that would undermine the whole regional development policy.
The only final point I would make is just to challenge—so that it does not go unchallenged—the proposition that this Amendment as it stands is something which would be simple and easy to operate.
I must make it clear, for reasons which will be familiar to hon. Members by now, that with the form in which this tax is now devised and raised through the addition to the National Insurance stamp, it would not be practicable for the kind of reasons I elaborated on an earlier Amendment to operate an exemption of this kind.
But I again repeat what the Chief Secretary said in replying to the last debate—that the tax, by its nature, is one which as it is developed in the future, and, as more refined methods of administration can be introduced, is capable of considerable differentiation and selection. But for the reasons that have already been given, that is not possible this year, and the fears which hon. Member's have expressed in this debate, in our view, are wholly exaggerated and do not justify their criticisms.

For several hours we have listened to debates connected with much the same subject, and, if it is a fault on the part of my hon. Friends who have taken part in this debate that they did not take part in the earlier ones, I hope that the Financial Secretary will excuse it. I saw seven or eight of my hon. Friends standing at every opportunity in the hope of getting in, but they did not have the good fortune to catch the eye of the Chair. [HON. MEMBERS: "And before the Closure, too."] Yes.
The Financial Secretary returned to, though he did not quote again, the list of things which the Chief Secretary gave at the end of our last debate in an attempt to persuade us that it was the totality of measures which the Government were trying to take for the different regions which should be looked at and not the pernicious effect of this tax on its own. No one who has studied these matters as an economist or a specialist in any of the regions doubts what the effect of the tax will be on regional policy. But the attempt was made to say that so many things had been done that the pernicious effect of the tax would not be nearly so serious as we have said.
We are told about the control of office building. This may at some stage be useful, but everyone who has seen what has actually been happening in the last few months knows that the office buildings are going not to the development areas and the places where we need them, but to the London periphery and the Sourh-East. The moving of the Post Office Savings Bank to Glasgow, and so on, was the result of action taken some years ago. There is no advantage to the development areas there.
If the right hon. Gentleman can tell me of some big office buildings which are going to the development areas, I shall gladly give him the opportunity.
Not on this Amendment.

I suspect that the Chancellor has to do some research in the hope of finding some. But these were the arguments which his colleagues put
to the Committee, so we are entitled to ask questions about them.
Next, the question of advance factories. If the rest of the country measures up at all to the pattern which has been seen in Scotland, the advance factories will be 90 per cent. in the central belt, in the very area where we do not at the moment need all this extra employment. These actions will be of no help in solving the problem.
The Chief Secretary spoke of special help from the banks for the development areas. This is a point of the greatest importance in our future discussion on the tax. Will the Chancellor allow the banks to give overdrafts to meet the forced loans which many people will have to pay? We have not been told.
If the Chief Secretary had attended the sittings of the Committee on the Industrial Development Bill, he could not have made the remarkably naive remarks he made about that Measure tonight. Plainly, he has not even read the reports of its proceedings. Over and over again, my hon. Friends and I, sometimes supported by hon. Members opposite, have moved Amendments exactly in line with the thoughts which have been in the mind of the Committee on this Amendment, and every time the President of the Board of Trade or the Minister of State has had to say that, even if he agreed with the sentiment, it was totally impossible to do anything about it. All the Government have told us about what they are doing to counterbalance the damage that the tax will do in these areas is words, not action. I am sure that my hon. Friends are right to have doubts about the Government's intentions.
The hon. and learned Gentleman said that he had had a great deal of help from the benches behind him in confuting some of the arguments that had been made. What help did he have? He did not have a speech, as one might well have expected, from the hon. Member for Caithness and Sutherland (Mr. Maclennan), one of the people particularly involved, or one from the hon. Member for the Western Isles (Mr. Malcolm MacMillan). But every one of their constituents knows just how damaging this tax will be in their areas. He did not have a speech from the hon.
Member for West Stirlingshire (Mr. W. Baxter), who tabled Amendment No. 360; though it has not been selected, I have no doubt that the hon. Member would not have given much comfort to the Financial Secretary.
But the hon. and learned Gentleman got a speech from the hon. Member for Dundee, West (Mr. Doig), who said that he did not care whether the unemployment in Scotland was double the national average or not, a rather curious statement to put on the record even though he said that the thing that mattered to him was the number. Surely the hon. Gentleman resents very much—at least all his hon. Friends did when they were in Opposition—that Scotland should have double the national average.
We got a lecture from the hon. Member for Aberdeen, South (Mr. Dewar), who came into the Committee for a few moments and then gave us a tremendous amount of advice about how we should carry on our debates. He missed the whole point of all the arguments when he said that he resented this being called a Scottish emigration tax. If he knew his own area—he may well not, because he comes from a good distance away from it—he would know very well that the problem in the North-East is the steady emigration of the skilled and best people from the area.
Mr. Dewar rose——

I will give the hon. Gentleman a chance in a moment. He must allow me to develop my argument before he attempts to demolish it.
The hon. Gentleman said that selectivity was absolutely essential and that if we had development areas with a higher rate of selectivity and, thus, advantages over other parts, it would wreck the whole scheme. He said that within the development area everything had to be the same. [Interruption.] Is the hon. Gentleman trying to put his case in a different form?

I recognised that the problem in my constituency was emigration, but because it is emigration, I am blessed in a back-handed way by having a very low unemployment rate. The Amendment—we are discussing that and not the Selective Employment Tax—
would particularly victimise my constituency, which would be at a considerable disadvantage compared with other development areas.

That is almost exactly the same argument as the hon. Gentleman used before. The point that he is in grave danger of missing—it is a very valid one in Scotland as a whole—is that in a situation where we have the whole of Scotland, with one small exception, as a development area the incentives for industry to settle in the middle are now very much greater than they have ever been before. Under other action which the Government have taken, and particularly under the impact of this tax and the withdrawal of the investment allowances, transport costs in Scotland have risen and will rise very greatly. Thus, the opportunity for industries to go to places like the hon. Member's area and settle there are much less than before. His area is in grave danger of suffering severely.

The right hon. Gentleman is avoiding the point. He is again making a general point about the tax, which may or may not be valid, and is avoiding argument about the Amendment, which would make worse the dangers he accurately describes.

I do not think that I can go on with this ad infinitum, but that is not necessarily so. The hon. Gentleman quoted one way in which it could happen. I am arguing that it is much more important to attract industry to development areas, perhaps with special help such as could be given by this tax, rather than to pursue the present policy of the Government which, if unwillingly, they are trying to persuade the Committee they are forced to follow.
When we come to other parts of the Bill there will be opportunity for points which the Government have not answered to be followed up, so I will not ask the Financial Secretary to go into them now. But I do ask him to bear in mind that, at some stage during the proceedings of the Bill, it will be the duty of the Government to tell us categorically what their estimate is of the cost of this tax to certain specified areas.
The calculations I have heard made for the Highlands range between £1½ million and £4½ million. No one can tell
us what is the best calculation at the moment. I asked the Chairman of the Highland Development Board last Friday and he said that he had been unable to get any accurate calculation. Whether the Government like it or not, it is true that, at least for the next six or nine months, a great deal more money will be drawn out of these areas than they can reasonably stand.
The hon. and learned Gentleman said that, of course, the Government had to raise revenue. Both he and the Chief Secretary have, as usual, asked us how else we would have raised it. Perhaps it might have gone on to transport and if
so, those of us living in outlying parts of the country would have disliked that, perhaps, even more.

The fact is simple. The money had to be raised—perhaps—but there were many other ways in which it could have been raised with very much less damage to development areas and to the employment situation within them. That being so, we will, I know, want to divide the Committee.
Question put, That those words be there inserted: —
The Committee divided: Ayes 90, Noes 134.

tr.td: Mr. David Mitchell and Mr. Younger.
Gordon Walker, Rt. Hn. P. C.

speech.p:
I beg to move, That the Chairman do report Progress and ask leave to sit again. I can understand the jubilation of the right hon. Member for Enfield, West (Mr. Iain Macleod). Looking back 12 months, however, if we had thought that there was any conceivable possibility of having a majority of 44 in a Division, we should have thought that we were well away—and we still think that.
This is a good time to report Progress. It is time that we gave the Opposition an opportunity to recharge their batteries and to find some fresh arguments. In view of the tedious arguments which we have been listening to, repeated time after time, it is only fair that they should have an opportunity to think up something a little new to beguile the time.

It is very dangerous to make statements like that. There is no reason why we should not debate this Motion for another two hours until the First Secretary arrives, tired as usual from his labours, and bullies the Deputy Chief
Whip into doing something he does not want to do; and then everybody gets very bad tempered with everybody else.
The Government's majorities have been very small. I do not make too much of that point. The arguments from this side of the Committee have been both concise and admirably phrased. The only thing which has gone wrong has been the consistent attempts of the Government and of the Government Chief Whip to closure the debates even on such important matters as development and the problems of the sick and disabled. If he had not just been beaten to the gun, he would have closured the debate on the last Amendment concerning the key development districts with relatively high rates of unemployment.
I suggest to the Chancellor that, after his experience yesterday, a certain amount of humility may help in making progress with the Bill.

p.i: Committee report Progress; to sit again this day.

speech.p: Motion made, and Question proposed, That this House do now adjourn.—[Mr. Charles R. Morris.]

I am grateful to my right hon. Friend the Minister of Housing and Local Government for being present at this hour of the morning to reply to the first Parliamentary debate on Manchester's water needs since the somewhat repetitive and rather eccentric debate held in another place on 9th February, 1962.
First, I should like to congratulate my right hon. Friend on the judgment he has made concerning Manchester's application to abstract water from Ullswater and Windermere. It is less easy to congratulate him on the time he took to reach that judgment, although I well understand the difficulties which faced him on a subject about which there has been such conflict between emotion and logic. My right hon. Friend will know that Manchester has readily given the assurance about public access to Hawes-water which was asked for in paragraph 36 of the decision letter. I hope that there will thus be no further delay in making and laying the Order before Parliament.
For my part, what I found disconcerting about the decision letter was its insistence on 1980 as the date by which another major source of water ought to be available to be brought into use. In paragraph 36 of the letter, the proposals to allow water to be taken from Ullswater and Windermere are said to be designed to meet the Manchester water undertaking's needs "until 1980 or thereabouts". The letter also appears to accept the assumption that between 1970 and 1980—and I quote from paragraph 6— the demand on Manchester will increase no faster than at present. In my view, that it is an entirely wrong assumption.
Manchester has been advised by consultant water engineers that there should be a margin of 10 per cent. of resources
over demand to meet contingencies, and an estimate based upon the current trend of consumption shows that demand will overtake the yield of all resources, including the full Ullswater and Windermere proposals, by 1974 or 1975.
Of course, we have not been given the full Ullswater and Windermere proposals. My right hon. Friend's decision on the City's draft Water Order will have the effect of reducing the supply from Ullswater from 25 million gallons a day to 20 million gallons a day, with the result that it would seem prudent to take 1974, or even 1973, as the year when another major source of supply should be available for use.
Moreover, if we are not to have a serious and avoidable water shortage in the mid-1970s, the new source should be identified this year. I emphasise this because, as the experience of both Liverpool and Manchester has shown, it takes a minimum of three years to design a scheme and obtain authority and a minimum of five years to acquire all the lands and easements and carry out the work of construction.
The idea that the demand upon Manchester will increase no faster than at present is not only myopic. It is also utterly inconsistent with our plans for sustained economic growth. It has been estimated that about 3 million people already rely, directly or indirectly, on water supplied by the Manchester undertaking. Manchester quite literally "carries the can" for more than two dozen of its neighbouring authorities in the North-West. As population increases, as standards of living improve and industry demands more and more water, the quantity available must be stepped up.
With more sophisticated production techniques and the expansion of such industries as chemical manufacturing and food processing the requirement is for water of a high and constant quality. The importance to the north-west region of having an adequate supply of water available wherever it may be needed has frequently been demonstrated. The availability of assured supplies for many years ahead is often a key factor in the location of new industry, or in the expansion of existing industry, with consequent benefit to the region.
Where, then, is Manchester's major new source of supply to be found? In the proposed estuarial barrage schemes? My right hon. Friend the Minister of Land and Natural Resources, in reply to a Question on 23rd May, told me that even on the most optimistic assumptions a barrage scheme at Morecambe Bay would not make water available till the early 1980s. Neither this nor desalination will provide the answer to the problem I have outlined.
It is, however, interesting to compare my right hon. Friend's reply of 23rd May with the statement made by the late Lord Birkett, when, in the last Parliamentary debate on Manchester's water needs, he referred to the possibility of distilling seawater as something which is just around the corner". Manchester's leading adversary was as badly wrong in saying this as he was in stating that the Ullswater and Windermere proposals were of no urgency, when he went on: I emphasised as strongly as I could the fact that there is no note of urgency about this matter at all".—[OFFICIAL REPORT, House of Lords. 8th February, 1962; Vol. 237, c. 236.] Very soon afterwards, in the spring of 1963, the Jellicoe Report was published and showed that the Manchester undertaking might have insufficient water to meet its obligations at any time after 1965. It went on to agree that the city should make plans for the provision, possibly by stages, of an additional reliable yield of about 50 million gallons a day "as a matter of urgency". I put it to my right hon. Friend that it is now even more urgent to identify a major new source of supply this year. Indeed, urgency has rarely been more urgent.
At the meeting my right hon. Friend attended with representatives of the Manchester City Council on 26th May it was agreed that, since Morecambe Bay or desalination would not be ready before 180, other works would have to be provided to meet the long-term needs of the North-West for water and that the Water Resources Board should now consider a limited number of possible schemes likely to be most suitable and prepare a list of possible schemes for consideration by the Minister in the autumn, so that a programme of investigations can then be planned. It was also agreed that Man-
Chester would be kept in touch with progress through the Mersey and Weaver River authority. Manchester very much welcomes those agreed arrangements and would like to see the programme of investigations proceed as quickly as possible.
I feel sure that my right hon. Friend can be relied upon to do all in his power to help. Water has the distinction of being a basic requirement of life and the No. 1 raw material of industry; and social and economic planning is about nothing if it is not about this. To recall a phrase used at the Kendal public inquiry, last June, the millions of people and the enormous industrial interests which rely on having water available cannot be expected to continue living "on a meteorological razor's edge".

I am very grateful to the hon. Member for Manchester, Wythenshawe (Mr. Alfred Morris) for giving me the opportunity to say a few words in this debate, because the whole of Lake Windermere and part of Ullswater are in my constituency, and hence I am very much involved.
This is not the time or the place to start a long discussion on the draft Manchester Water Order on which the Minister made his decision a few weeks ago. That, of course, was a short-term solution to the problem, as the Minister said in answer to a Question of mine on 16th May. He told me that he regarded one of the alternative schemes put up at the public inquiry as a possible long-term solution and the draft Order as a short-term one. Hence, I do not feel that the draft Water Order comes within the terms of the debate, which deals with the long-term needs.
In passing, may I say that it is a very bad decision for the Lake District. It is one which would make the great Lord Birkett turn in his grave. Whether the Minister likes it or not, it means that Manchester would have a foot in the door of Ullswater, and, whatever he may say now or in the future, as he says in his decision letter, he cannot bind his successors under any circumstances. This is the part of the decision which gives rise to most fears and causes most concern in the Lake District.
With regard to the long-term proposals and the long-term needs for Manchester, there is not and never has been a dog-in-the-manger attitude by those concerned with the Lake District. There is a great deal of floodwater which runs down to the sea from that part of England, and we must look very hard at the Solway proposal, as is happening already. There is a great deal of waste hydroelectric water which runs to the sea at that place, and it may well be that that waste hydro-electric water could provide the key to Manchester's long-term needs.
There were alternative schemes put up at the public inquiry, as the Minister knows. I hope that those will be looked at properly in the time ahead. I am sure that the Minister, will tell us that the Water Resources Board will be looking at all these needs and at all the possibilities. I hope that he will tell us just what mandate the Water Resources Board will have in looking at the water resources of the north-west, and that he will tell us just how it will go about its business.
The great objection to Manchester's approaches in the past has been that the city seemed to people in the Lake District to want water at the least possible cost, regardless of the amenities of the area. It is those amenities which are most jealously guarded by the people who live in the Lake District.

I did not refer to amenity, but I hope that the hon. Member for Westmorland (Mr. Jopling) will take it from me that Manchester people are not against scenic beauty. They are as keen to preserve scenic beauty as anyone else and——
Order. We cannot have long interventions when a Minister is waiting to reply.

The one assurance that I would like from the Minister this morning is about the Winster Valley. That is one place at which Manchester has already made a set. While the Minister cannot bind his successors, we would like an assurance from him that, as long as he holds his present office, he will not be a party to having that magnificent valley flooded. We would like to know whether he agrees with Mr. Carter, the Chairman of the North-Western Economic Planning
Council, that to flood the valley would be unthinkable.
The Lake District has a very special and a very brittle beauty. The amenities of it are not expendable, in any circumstances. Above all, there should be no panic measures in the future, because of the crisis which is approaching Manchester, to attempt to use the lakes for an emergency situation.

speech.speakername: The Minister of Housing and Local Government (Mr. Richard Crossman)
speech.p:
I am grateful to my hon. Friend the Member for Manchester, Wythenshawe (Mr. Alfred Morris) for raising this issue, and I hope that he will realise that the importance which I attach to it is indicated by the time in the morning when I have decided to reply to him.
My hon. Friend is quite right in saying that the belief that we can wait until 1980 for a further source of supply for Manchester is unrealistic. I would say to the hon. Member for Westmorland (Mr. Jopling) that those who waited would find themselves under pressure to undermine the safeguarding of the lakes which I have been trying to write into the new Order. There is no delay about the new Order. It is with the printers, and it will be made as soon as it comes back, either at the end of this week, or next week, so there will be an opportunity to see it and discuss it.
It is true that on Manchester's calculations some further supplies will be necessary by 1973–74–75, and I am urgently concerned, with the Water Resources Board, in trying to find these further supplies in good time. It is also true that the severe cutting back of Manchester's supply from Ullswater, implicit in the new Order, makes this search for supplies even more important.
There are one or two things which I should like to say about sources of supply. I think that we can rule out the More-cambe Bay barrage or the Solway as producing water before 1980. It may be good for the second range of supply, but for the first instance it would not be good enough. We can also rule out desalination for the period of the 'seventies, and for this period, therefore, we have to look elsewhere.
As my hon. Friend knows, I am making sure that the Water Resources
Board, which I have invited to do this, shall before the end of this year draw up a list of conventional water schemes for urgent investigation. The Board has promised that this will be done, and we will start this work before the end of this year.
The Board has a Northern Committee which is assessing long-term demands and resources for the whole of the North of England. It includes the technical officers of all the river authorities concerned and of the principal water undertakers—including, of course, Manchester. Its study will cover the period up to the end of the century, and will take account of river regulation works, direct abstraction from inland water and underground plus barrages and desalination.
But, as I have said, the Committee's immediate task, which it is accelerating at my request, will be to prepare a short list of schemes for Manchester and South-East Lancashire on which urgent detailed investigation must be concentrated. When this report is ready, my officers and I will meet the Board and discuss the proposals. Manchester will, of course, be fully associated with the discussion.
Manchester has asked whether it should be setting its own consultants to work on new projects for the long term. I believe that the Board wants me to discourage that, because it is the job of
the Water Resources Board and the river authorities to do the exploratory work which, in the past, was left to the individual water undertaker, or was neglected. This exploratory work is now being done by the Northern Committee.
When the preliminaries have been completed and a short list of possible projects drawn up, I want Manchester and its consultants to undertake detailed further investigation of some of these projects which look likely, others being left to the river authority concerned. Manchester need be in no doubt that its co-operation will be used to the full, but this time it will be under the general direction of the Board and of my Ministry.
There will be nothing more from Ullswater. There will be no more artificial reservoirs like Winster Valley. There will not be any more of that sort of thing, but we must look forward to the long-term. We have to look at the lower reaches of the rivers in this region. This is the area on which we are concentrating our attention, and I can tell both hon. Members that on this occasion the exploration is taking place early enough to provide the necessary interim solution in the mid-seventies, before the major solution of the 'eighties.

p.i: Adjourned accordingly at one minute to Eight o'clock a.m.
